Award.AwardTitle: Research On Fluctuations of Gravity and Quantum Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will entail theoretical studies of several aspects of quantum fluctuations of spacetime and related issues. A key problem in any quantum theory of gravity is understanding these fluctuations and their physical effects. One will be the effects of quantum energy density fluctuation in the early universe, especially in the context of inflationary cosmology. Previous studies by the PI and his collaborators indicate that these effects may be larger than one would have naively guessed, and possibly large enough to cause observable effects today. A related topic is the study of the probability distribution for quantum energy density fluctuations. A better understanding of this distribution, especially the part which describes rare but large fluctuations, can have applications to several questions in quantum theory and cosmology. Other aspects of the project will include a search for secular effects from quantum gravity fluctuations, that is, effects which can accumulate over the history of the universe. If such effects exist and can be detected, it would lead to significant insights. The project will also involve a search for laboratory experiments to detect such effects as negative energy and lightcone fluctuations in analog systems.

This project is expected to have a broader impact through possible benefits to other fields of science, to education, and to technology. The insights and techniques of this work may be useful outside of the specific subfields of physics being investigated. The project is expected to further education through the involvement of graduate students and of faculty at primarily teaching institutions. It should also produce examples which can be used to explain some of the concepts of quantum theory and relativity to students on a variety of educational levels. The results of some of the investigations in this project may be useful in other fields of physics, such as atomic physics and condensed matter physics, and might eventually have technological applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has dealt with selected problems of quantum fluctuations, and their role in a deeper understanding of gravitation. Quantum fluctuations are a consequence of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, and are a common feature of atomic and subatomic systems. This project has elucudated some new effects, which had not been understood before,

One of these effects involves fluctuations in the energy density in a small but finite region of space. Even when there is no matter or particles present in this region, there can still be a fluctuating energy density. The average value fo the energy density may be zero,  but repeated measurements of the energy density will typically yield nonzero values, which can be either positive or negative. Positive energy density. like ordinary matter. produces an attractive gravitational field. Negative energy density, which can be likened to a local energy debt, produces repulsive gravity. A key result of the project is a mathematical description of the probability for finding different values for the energy density, or more precisely of the time average of the energy density over a short interval. This description has two striking features. One is the existence of a strict lower bound, which prevents the energy density from being too negative, a type of debt limit. The other feature is that large, positive fluctuations are much more likely than had previously been expected. These large energy density fluctuations may have interesting consequences in cosmology, in the search for a quantum theory of gravity, and in other areas of physics. These consequences are a topic for further research.

Another effect studied in this project is quantum fluctuations of the speed of light. Einstein's classical theory of relativity takes the speed of light as an absolute, unchangeable quantity. However, quantum theory suggests that even the speed of light must fluctuate, as a consequence of fluctuations of the gravitational field. This effect had been studied theoretically in the past, but is much too small to observe with current technology.  The project involved a study of analog models, which have many of the same features as quantum gravity, but in systems which might be realizable in the laboratory. Specifically, we examined quantum fluctuations in the speed of light in nonlinear dielectric materials. This study served to clarify the basic principles at work, and also may lead to realistic experiments.

The project had broader impacts especially in education. Several students on different levels, ranging from high school to graduate school participated in the project and benefited from their experiences. Some of the results of the research can be valuable in illustrating subtle scientific concepts to student and to the public in general. The results on the probability of large energy density fluctuations is an example. It is an example where the probability of a rare event is rather larger than one would have guessed.
